If that should be the result - and I have no doubt that it would be - this is the most important move that could be made at the present juncture at an international conference.
- How do the hours in Australia compare with those in other countries?

- We are behind some countries, but ahead of others. There was a time when we could boast that we were in the van of all other countries with our industrial legislation and progress; but we cannot say that to-day. If our government delegates do not adopt a progressive stand, Australia will be marked among the nations of the world as one of the most backward. That is shown by the resolution to which I have referred, which indicates that the nations are prepared to consider favorably and seriously a reduction of the hours of labour. I have no wish to mislead honorable members. That resolution did not necessarily adopt a reduction of hours; but it did declare that a reduction of hours would have the effect of reducing unemployment - a very important declaration which, as I interpret it, carried with it an endorsement of the reduction of hours. Although at that stage the government delegates would not commit themselves to a specified number, the subject that they discussed was a 40-hour week. As a significant sign of the times, I quote the following from a cablegram that appeared in the press of the 5th instant, under the heading " Thirty Hour Week "; "Bill in the United States of America Congress": -

quote.para: Legislation to establish a 30-hour week was taken up by the Senate for consideration on Monday, about the same time as the bill emerged' from the House of Representatives' Labour Committee with the unanimous, approval of the committee. The bill would compel private industry to adopt a 30-hour week, and would penalize the interstate movement of products made by labour working longer hours, l t is not expected that the Senate will vote on the measure before Monday.

talk.start.para: - Nothing is said about remuneration.
- That question is not raised. Obviously, however, there could not be a corresponding reduction of the remuneration, at any rate in a basic way; because that would merely be a rationing of labour.
- That is the big obstacle to the adoption of such &t proposal.

- I do not see why it should be, particularly if it were adopted - internationally. In what way is there to bc consumption of the goods that are produced in abundance to-day by the modern methods of production? The only way is . to have an increased purchasing power with a lessening of the hours of those who are engaged in production. I shall not say that it. can only bc done internationally; but it would be very much easier for Aus-' tralia to take this action if other countries kept in step with it. Whatever attitude the Government may adopt on the internal aspect of the question, I should say that, in the interests of the nation as a nation, it should support a reduction of hours at an international, conference, because Australia would have everything to gain, and I believe nothing to lose, by the adoption internationally of a reduction of the hours of labour. 1 am not so optimistic as. to believe that even the resolution carried at Geneva will automatically have the result of giving effect to the proposal that it supports. But that would not justify our opposing it. On the contrary, it would warrant our urging the government delegates, not only to support it, but also to advocate that it be put into practice; because the problem which confronts Australia, with its army of unemployed, confronts every country in the world to-day. I have no doubt that honorable members have read of the remarkable progress that has been made, in the methods of production by means of machinery; therefore, it is not necessary for me to elaborate that aspect of the matter. I merely make one or two quotations from a case that has been well prepared by the Melbourne trade union movement -

quote.para: The chief mechanical engineer of the South Australian railways said that, as a result of the installation of modern machines, and improved methods, 800 men at the Islington workshops were doing the same amount oi work as 1,800 men did in 1925.

talk.start.para: - In 1925 there was a surplus number of men at Islington workshops.
- This statement says that 800 men are doing the same amount of work as was done by 1,800 in that year. Another statement reads -

quote.para: Addressing the Management Association last year, the Managing Director of. Pelaco Limited said that in 1911, 300 dozen collars a week were being stamped in the factory, but with increased efficiency, one girl alone now stamped 4,400 dozen a week.

speech.para: Some of the statements that are made are almost unbelievable; yet they are backed up by engineers, scientific and practical men who are in control of industry. The displacement of labour by machinery has increased enormously within recent years, and unless the problem is tackled nothing but starvation, ruin, and probably revolution, will face the nations of the world. One of the practical steps that can be taken - and it is not the only one - is the reduction of the hours of labour; and one of the best ways in which that can be brought about is on an international basis. I again urge the Government to instruct its delegates to support such a proposal.

talk.start.para: .- Any reform that would tend to relieve the social and economic consequences of unemployment would be most welcome, so long as the disadvantages were not greater than the advantages. I believe that the advantages of what might be called a snap debate on this subject are fairly limited, because it is a most technical subject. Few of us have had the privilege of studying the leading publications on the subject. They really do not carry us very far, beyond stating the plus and the minus views put forward by delegates representing the workers, the employers and the different governments. At the recent conference of the International Labour Office heM in Geneva, the reasons- given by the representatives of the workers and the employers were what one would imagine they would be. The interesting point, in my opinion, is that the Government delegates - not by any means unanimously, but by a majority - decided that, generally speaking, they were in favour of a reduction of hours. But the matter does not end there. I do not consider that one can draw a final conclusion, or anything approaching it, from the recommendations of that January conference. Presumably, the resolutions then adopted are to be referred to the next conference of the International Labour Office that is to be held in June next, and not to the World Economic Conference. The difficulty that I see, and that I think every one sees, is the almost impossibility of achieving the object that is sought without the universal adoption of a shorter week by all the principal manufacturing countries. The difficulty of getting any two nations to agree to the same thing at the same time is almost insuperable, let alone securing unanimity among most of the manufacturing nations of the world. Without a generally accepted scheme, I do not see how the proposal could be put into effect. It would be the same as with disarmament, reduction of tariffs, and similar movements .which have been attempted during the last ten years, requiring uniform action by nations which think that the' proposals will not have uniform effects on their economy. I am not particularly hopeful that anything practicable will come out of this movement. Steps have been taken in several individual countries and industries to reduce hours of labour. As far back as 1926 the Ford Motor Company in America, and in some of its foreign branches, reduced the working week to 40 hours, and the system has been maintained up to the present time. But the reforms introduced by that company do not seem to be suitable for universal adoption. In Germany, the number of working hours has been reduced in certain industries; but conditions there are particularly favorable for such an experiment, because government control over industry is greater in Germany than in any other country outside Russia and Italy.

speech.para: It might be possible to make a start in the form of regional agreements for the restriction of hours in certain definite industries; but, again, I am glad that I shall not have to frame rules and regulations whereby any such arrangement would be implemented. The task would be colossal. The Leader of the Opposition^ (Mr. Scullin) spoke of technological unemployment. A point which I gleaned from the International Labour

Office publications was that in Germany, at least, technological unemployment was a relatively small part, rather less than 20 per cent, of the total unemployment, and I expect that Germany is typical of most manufacturing countries. References to technocracy, have .flooded the American press for the last twelve months ; but I confess that I cannot take the matter seriously, because I do not see how it can be put into effect, except under a system of communism, providing for complete control by the State of human activities.

A short debate on a subject of this complexity is not very useful. It is a most complicated and technical subject. I await with a great deal of interest what the Acting Leader of the House (Mr. Latham) will say on the matter; but it seems to me that the making of a hard and fast decision at this time, with the limited knowledge at our disposal, is something which he will probably hesitate to do. Another point emphasized in the League of Nations publications is that this is not a subject by itself. It would be all right if we could put the proposal into effect, and get the obvious result hoped for ; but there are all sorts of complications as between one industry and another, and as between small industries only partially mechanized, and large industries wholly mechanized. There are also difficulties in regard to overtime and part time. Then there is the interesting possibility that any suggestion like this, if put into effect, might quite well be. a definite encouragement to mechanization, and, if that were to happen, it would defeat the whole object of the movement. This is an interesting subject; but we cannot discuss it to any advantage in the short time available to us this afternoon.

talk.start.para: . - I endorse the opinions expressed by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Scullin) on this important subject. I realize that not very much can be achieved by one nation seeking to reduce the number of working hours without the co-operation of other countries with which it trades. Those who support a long working week do not understand the part that machinery has played in displacing human labour. The time has arrived when something must be done to overcome the difficulty which has been created. Recently, an inquiry was held into working hours on the New South Wales railways. Evidence was given by the chief industrial officer for the railways department, Mr. Gerald Hall, that if the working week was increased from 44 hours to 48, work on the railways could be carried on with 1,569 fewer employees. He estimated that in this way the department would save 350,000 a year, less 120,000 paid by way of compensation. He said that, by increasing the working week to 48 hours, the same output would be obtained from eleven-twelfths of the present staff. A simple arithmetical calculation shows this to be true, and the effect would be to displace one man in every twelve. Dealing with the disposal of the surplus staff, the witness said that only those with more than ten years' service would receive pensions; the others would receive gratuities. When the scheme is carried out, the effect will be that one man in every twelve will be placed on the dole. The State Government assumes an attitude of indifference in the face of this tragic possibility. I mix freely with these men, and realize that they are able and anxious to work. It is not right that they and their families . should be compelled to subsist on what is barely sufficient to support human life. The - Federal Government should interest itself in this matter, and assist the State Governments; which have a gigantic task, in maintaining the unemployed. I have frequently put this proposal before the Commonwealth Government, but have been told that it is exclusively a matter for the State Governments. Surely the health and welfare of the citizens of Australia are of interest to this Government. We know that, at the present time, the Commonwealth Government is taking action against the occupants of war service homes, and actually forcing into the streets at the approach of winter persons who risked their lives for their country. Yet we claim that we are Christians, living in an enlightened age. Four years ago, on a similar occasion to this, I pleaded with the Government of the day to assist the destitute miners of northern New South Wales. I said that honorable members, parading as Christians, were returning to their homes to com- memorate the sacrifice of the lowly Nazarene. Again that annual commemoration has come round, and some honorable members will attend their churches during Easter. What are they doing, to put into effect the principles they profess, towards assisting the thousands who are homeless, without food and shelter ? Where is our vaunted Christianity when we permit these things to exist? It is a tragedy that testimony should be forthcoming from hospitals that women have to be admitted suffering from privation and malnutrition. In one instance, a destitute woman, weak from want of food, was admitted to hospital suckling a child. Yet the Government remains apathetic and inactive. I am not pleading for those who, as some claim, are unemployable. There are thousands of honest persons who are only too anxious and willing to work if given the opportunity. Even if people cannot get work, they have the right to live. It is well known that Australia is a country possessing vast spaces awaiting development and enjoying advantages incomparably better than those which exist elsewhere. All that is necessary is to obtain loan money to be expended by State governments and local authorities on developmental work that is revenue producing. The proposal of the Scullin Government to use the credit resources of the nation and make available 20,000,000 for developmental work was hailed with derision, the present acting Leader of the House (Mr. Latham) saying that it was inflation which would cause further distress. Yet if there were a war to-morrow, the honorable gentleman and his supporters would raise a vastly greater sum for the slaughter of human beings. Be it termed inflation or any other name, if the method is good enough to raise money to kill people, it is good enough to raise money to keep people alive by providing them with employment on works of a reproductive nature.

speech.para: I realize that at the forthcoming International Labour Conference, different nations will advance arguments against a reduction of the hours of labour in industry, but as has been said by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Scullin), the United States of America has# already taken a step in the proper direction by introducing a bill to bring about a 30-hour week. Even if that does not solve, it will relieve, the problem. Taxation has reached saturation point. Half the people are taxed to provide sustenance for the remaining half. It is lamentable that the amount spent to provide the dole should total 9,000,000 per annum. Nobody can claim that, to collect money from those engaged in industry for the support of those in idleness, is either sane or sound political economy. It is simply tipping . money into a bottomless pit. It would be far better to reduce the hours of labour and give persons the privilege of working for their living. The dole weakens a person physically, because it is inadequate, and morally, because it is unsound. There . are some in Australia who have reached the age of 22 or 23 and have never done a day's work for a wage. It is tragic to think that some who are on the dole are marrying. _ I plead with the Government to make an honest endeavour to relieve the situation. The unemployed have looked in vain for the fulfilment of the specious promises that were made by this and other governments, that if elected they would evolve a solution of the problem by providing useful work. There is no hope of those promises being redeemed under the existing system of production for profit instead of for use. The Government must make up its mind to reduce the hours of labour in industry, and so, to some degree, offset the alarming displacement of human labour by machinery.

talk.start.para: .- The circumstances which give rise to this discussion are admitted by all to be extremely regrettable. This is a subject to which every responsible person has given consideration for a long time. I confess that the difficulties which present themselves baffle me entirely. I do not think that there is any short-cut or royal road that will substantially improve the situation. It will probably be found that a state of siege will exist because of the difficulties of securing effective international action in any matter, let alone a bread-and-butter one such as this which is really basic for the welfare of the various peoples of the world, and constitutes the field upon which all economic struggles of the past have been fought. Unemployment is caused by the present economic and monetary crisis and also by machinery. If- it were possible, which I think it is not, to secure a measure of agreement to reduce working hours to 40 hours a week, we should be x merely touching the fringe of this problem, if, indeed, we did not do something which would create more unemployment, instead of reducing it.

speech.para: I heard recently of a Rayon factory in America which was operating three shifts a day, and was completely unattended, as to operating labour, except for two or three attendant engineers. If the hours of attendance of those engineers could be reduced in any proportion that might be mentioned, that factory could still maintain its output, arid so one of the causes of unemployment would still remain. The advance in technical methods of production has been so extremely swift that it seems almost hopeless for us, by any adjustment, to overtake it.

talk.start.para: - What is the alternative ?

- I shall come to that as I develop my argument. Anything in the nature of re-adjustment would have to be done by international accord, which it would be extremely difficult, if not impossible, to obtain. It is not only the factory working population which comes into this picture. Surely if hours are reduced in secondary production they must also be reduced in primary production. I am not very confident that our agricultural and land industries generally would permit of such regulation as a reduction of the working week to 40 hours implies.' I do not think that we can fix these things so nicely, in landed industries as in manufacturing industries. I picture to myself the French peasant working on his small holding of land and mainly concerned with the production of his own immediate wants in food, and also the field labourers of Egypt and Asiatic countries, and of Japan. Even if it were decided to restrict the working week by a given number of hours how could such , a decision be policed?
- The honorable member has already said that the peasant will not work any more than is necessary to produce the food he wants.
- That is so; but it is his habit to work.
- The honorable member has said that he does not exploit the market for his own ends.

- There are certain instances that may be mentioned in which the work available has been spread over a greater number of people. Various methods have been employed to this end, such as the rationing of work, as well as the definite shortening of working hours to permit the engagement of additional personnel. Some go'vernments have encouraged private employers to provide extra employment by rationing, and in certain cases private employers have responded to the suggestion. In other cases governments and local governing bodies have set an example in the employment of more men by authorizing the shortening of the working week on government and municipal jobs. Again, Germany has passed legislation on the subject, but the legislation has been more in the nature of a pious hope than of anything really enforcible, for underlying the legislation is a principle that cannot be avoided. The hours worked in Germany have not been statutorily reduced by any fixed limitation. The Government has merely urged the parties to industry to come together and agree to a reduction, but only where it is " technically and economically possible." That is the test of the whole thing. Can it be done technically and economically? I shall try to answer that question by reference to some of our own industries. It is not enough for us to instruct our delegate at Geneva to endorse any action for a reduction of hours. If any such instruction is to carry the weight which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Scullin) would like it to carry, the thing must become an international compact, and then it must be translated into action in the various countries concerned. In Australia rationing is a fairly common practice, but in many industries rationing is not possible because of the specialized character of the work, and even where it is applied it invariably increases costs. In a country situated as Australia is, there is a limit to the extent to which costs can be increased.

speech.para: Again, where governments have set an example by limiting the hours to 40 per week on government and municipal jobs, the further question arises : whether governments can afford the extra cost of such works which have to be paid for by the people through taxation? If there is throughout the land to-day, one cry that is more insistent than another, it is the demand for a reduction of taxation as a means of reopening avenues of employment which increased taxation has closed. A lengthening of hours will, undoubtedly, mean that government works will be more expensive than they are on the present scale of hours. As I remarked earlier, we must be careful that in shortening hours with the object of increasing employment, we do not actually reduce employment by increasing costs. More cannot be taken out of industry than is put into it. If, by the process of shortening the hours of work or of spreading employment by rationing or otherwise, costs are advanced, the point is soon reached when the life of the industry concerned becomes endangered. When that time comes an industry will not afford the security and volume of employment that it would if the margin were wider.

talk.start.para: - What are the costs in the industry mentioned by the honorable member which is carried on by two or three attendant engineers?

- We have no such factories in Australia. I am discussing Australian conditions and trying to answer the German proposition in relation to what is "technically and economically possible." We have industries in Australia to-day which are in a dormant condition awaiting the return of better times. We hope that the time will come before long when those industries will again employ labour; but I put it to honorable members that there will be better prospects of their revival and of the birth of other industries if the cost factor is kept in mind, and, through the cost factor, the hours of work. I hope that I shall be allowed to discuss the subject along these lines without being described as reactionary. Theoretically, I should like to see a 40-hour working week in general operation, but theory must not be allowed to run too far. Practical issues must be faced'. In the mining industry of Australia there is an outstanding instance in which the hours of work are less than 40 per week. I refer to Broken Hill, where the weekly hours of work are 35 underground, and 44 on the surface. But any one who knows the Broken Hill mining field also knows the reason for this. It is a system that could never have been reached but for the richness of the Broken Hill field. Even with that richness and with the Broken Hill companies operating to-day on a bigger tonnage than ever before, the shareholders are obtaining no returns, and the companies are able to sustain their operations only by the help of the exchange. At Mount Lyell in Tasmania, of which I have personal knowledge, there is a most up-to-date plant on which about 500,000 has been spent in the last five years for the purpose of increasing efficiency, and to meet the consistent decline of prices. But it may be said, without any equivocation whatever, that any serious alteration in the present industrial arrangements on that field, which would* have the effect of increasing costs, would undoubtedly close down the plant and react disastrously on the 10,000 or 12,000 people who are dependent upon it for their livelihood. To-day Western Australia, in consequence of the high price of gold, is enjoying a good time, but it is not very many years since the representatives of the mining companies of that State requested the Bruce-Page Government to grant a bounty on gold. They said that they could not treat the low grade ore deposits of from 5 dwt. to 6 dwt. without a bounty. It might be possible, under present conditions, to operate the more favoured properties in Western Australia on a 40-hour week; but it would not be possible to operate the less favoured of them under such conditions. Honorable members appreciate, I am sure, that once a standard is established in an industry it is very hard to depart from it. Suppose the exchange premium on gold disappears, and in the meantime we have introduced a 40-hour week in the goldenmile area in "Western Australia. "What happens ? Automatically those properties all go out, because they cannot then produce gold at a profit. So I impress upon honorable members that this thing is loaded. I would not have our delegates nearly as definite about the matter as the Leader of the Opposition has suggested they should be. Australia's role at this conference should be that of a sympathetic listener. As a small community, I do not believe that Australia has ever led the world in the way that has been, claimed for it, and I do not think that we can lead this conference, and drag the whole world after us. Rather, we should be content to play a minor part, showing our sympathy in the direction of a shorter working week, our hope being that the present calamitous position will be remedied at no distant date.

speech.para: Take another side of industry, that of continuous processes. In some countries, instead of three shifts of eight hours a day, there are now four shifts of six hours a day. It is quite a recent development. In this country, we have two great continuous processes, and I need mention only one of them - the Broken Hill Proprietary Company's' steel works at Newcastle. The introduction of four sixhour shifts into those works would inevitably be reflected in an increased cost of iron and steel products, and would at once hit back at the users of those products. I think that the primary industries would oppose any suggestion that, in order to provide more work at Newcastle, a system should he introduced which would bring about unemployment on the broad acres.

talk.start.para: - "Would not the honorable member take that stand?

- I think that I should. Therefore, I urge the Government not to be so definite as was suggested, but to realize that our representatives should go to the conference as sympathetic listeners, and with a watching brief.

. - I urge the Government to acquiesce in the request of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Scullin) to consider the advisability of instructing the Government delegates to vote for a reduction of hours of employment. I agree with the honorable member for Corio (Mr. Casey) that this is a deep-seated problem. The honorable member for Denison (Mr. Hutchin) has been raising old orthodox objections to such a reduction, considering the matter in the light of conditions that obtained a decade ago. For years, the Labour movement fought for the establishment of an eight-hour day, but the reasons advanced in support of that reform, even so late as eight or ten years ago, were not those which are now advanced for a reduction of hours. Those earlier reasons were moral and ethical only. They were that, owing to the laborious nature of their employment, men should not be asked to work for more than eight hours in 24. We then contended that it was bad, morally and phyically, for a man to be kept continuously at work for too long a period. But today, those same reasons are not advanced. It is now a matter of life and death - whether we are to keep half the people in the world out of work, and have them living on doles at the expense of the other half. The seriousness of this problem can be realized from the fact that the conference held at Geneva in January last was an emergency one, the first of the kind held for seventeen years. It was convened for the purpose of saving twelve months time; otherwise, this matter could not have been discussed and given its first reading until June next, and would then need to be deferred for twelve months for final decision. The governments of the world and employers of large manufacturing countries regarded, this subject of hours as so serious, and they had reached such a crisis in their economic circumstances, that they urged the League of Nations to convene a special conference in order to avoid a delay of twelve months. The conference accordingly met, and discussed a proposal that the International Labour Office should adopt a convention, and send out to its members a resolution for the introduction of a 40-hour working week, without loss of pay. The report that was submitted to the conference had, for six or seven months, occupied the attention of probably the greatest statisticians in the world. It shows that a 40-hour week and a six-hour working day are commonly observed in many parts of the -world. This has happened only in the last two or three years, and the reason is that all countries are confronted with the evil of over production. Productivity is going up by leaps and bounds ; but there is an insufficient demand for the goods that are produced. The surplus must either be destroyed in some manner, or be utilized, otherwise chaos will ensue. I draw the attention of honorable members to some figures that I have extracted from the American Monthly Review, of December, 1932. They show that productivity in various countries increased between 1923 and 1930 as follows: -

speech.para: The honorable member for Denison said that it was impossible to take more out of an industry than was put into it. The world has heard that statement for 100 years, and I confess that, on the surface, it sounds reasonable; but the problem with which we are faced to-day is to decide what we are to do with surplus products. Throughout the world the captains of industry are confronted with huge stocks, for which there is little demand, and they are being overwhelmed with those stocks. A 40-hour week and a six-hour working day in continuous processes are now in universal operation in modern workshops in the United States of America. I refer to the rubber, oil, metal, automobile, and all large manufacturing industries. In those industries, in which there are not continuous processes, a 40-hour week is observed. In Germany, 40 hours a week are worked in shipbuilding yards, glass works, oil works, rubber works, breweries, &c, and, where there are continuous processes, four sixhour shifts are worked. In Belgium, a 40-hour week is worked in glass and motor factories. In Bulgaria, the Government has practically ordered the tobacco industry to reduce the hours of employment from eight to seven a day. In Czechoslovakia, four six-hour shifts are worked, and in Poland 'six-hour shifts have been put into operation at the suggestion of the Government. For some time Italy has had a 40-hour working week, and where the process of manufacture is continuous, a working day of six hours. Italian employers suggested the change to the International Labour Office only after they had themselves put the new principle into operation. In the F.I.A.T. motor works at Turin, Italy, where 14,000 workers are employed, the 40-hour working week has been introduced with the fate of pay the same as it was when the working week covered 48 hours. By an arrangement entered into with the employees, there is a flexible two hours either way, in order to balance any fluctuation in the demand for the company's production. The company has guaranteed that no employee will be put off, that the pay will remain the same as before, and that at the end of the year matters will be adjusted on the basis of the hours actually worked. That agreement, which is one of the best industrial agreements of which I am aware, is working well. The reason for the change is not that the workers have demanded less hours. Employers, as well as the Italian Government, urged this reform, and the only thing which keeps the new movement back is the desire for uniformity throughout all manufacturing countries. Honorable members have seen in the press lately references to legislation which was recently introduced into the Senate of the United States of America, to give effect to a working week of 30 hours. That legislation proposes to prohibit interstate commerce in all commodities produced in establishments in which any person is employed for more than five days a week or six hours a day. A bill to the same effect has also been introduced in the House of Representatives, and referred to its Labour Committee. I quote these things to show what is in the minds of the people of the United States of America. They are not making this change for sentimental reasons, or because they think that six hours is long enough to work in any one day, but because of the crisis with which they are confronted ; it " is a matter of life or death. The resolution carried at Geneva is to become a recommendation for the conference to be held in June, and it is for that recommendation that we ask the Government to advise its delegates to vote. It was carried by a majority, which included 21 government delegates and 19 employees' delegates and one employers' delegate. Against the resolution were three government delegates and nineteen employers' delegates. Out of 24 government delegates, only three voted against the resolution. There must be some reason for that; it is a realization of the serious position of the world to-day and the necessity to call a halt' in the descent of prices. The position is entirely different from what it was ten years ago, when I argued in industrial courts that it was unreasonable to expect any man or woman to work more than eight hours a day. The arguments which were then advanced have since been cast overboard; to-day it is a question of what we shall do to enable the people to buy back the things which they are producing so rapidly. Every day this problem is becoming more and more acute; fewer people are working, and consequently the spending power of the nations is being reduced. The proposal for fewer hours to the working week is actuated by selfish motives, by an endeavour to bridge the gap between our power to produce things and our ability to buy them. The Douglas credit scheme and other schemes correctly diagnose the trouble, but not one of them supplies the complete remedy. The honorable member for Corio (Mr. Casey) admitted that the problem was too difficult for him to answer, and, consequently, he did not attempt to answer it. He expressed a doubt whether the new system would work unless every nation adopted it at the same time. We in this chamber probably do not believe in miracles, and are not over-sanguine that all the nations will adopt the new system at once. But there is a prospect of getting a group of leading manufacturers to adopt it. Already Mander Brothers, large producers of paints, varnishes, inks, oils and colours in England, have adopted a 40-hour working week at the same rate of pay that previously applied to a working -week of 47 hours. The German Government has set aside 700,000,000 reichmarks for the purpose of inducing employers to engage additional workers. For every extra man fitted into industry the employer responsible is to be subsidized to the extent of 400 marks per annum. That fund will provide sufficient money to enable 1,700,000 additional employees to be fitted into their own industries. That move has been made, not because the German people have larger hearts than we in Australia have, but because they know that something must be done to tackle this problem. I have information in my possession which shows that eminent professors in various countries are thinking along these same lines. I hope that the Acting Leader of the House (Mr. Latham) will do his best to induce the Government to adopt the suggestion of the Leader of the Opposition.

talk.start.para: .- The contributions made to the discussion by the honorable members for Corio (Mr. Casey) and Denison (Mr. Hutchin) were disappointing inasmuch as, while they admitted the existence of the industrial problem confronting the world, they expressed doubts about the economic soundness of the proposed solution. But is it not probable that they are unaware of the fundamental facts? In the development of our civilization, the application of science to industry, due, in a large measure, to the payment of bonuses and high salaries to leaders of industry, has resulted in an enormous increase in production, and threatens to overwhelm society. By this I mean that the world is now producing more than the people are capable of purchasing and consuming. It is estimated that, with mass-production methods, industry throughout the world is producing, with a 10 per cent, reduction in manpower, more than was produced ten years ago. The honorable member for Denison cited a case in point when he mentioned the astonishing output of what might be described as a Robot rayon factory, which required little personal super* vision. Similar developments are taking place in every branch of industry throughout the world, so that it imposes no strain on the imagination to visualize, in ten years' time, a reduction of 50 per cent, in man-power, and a greatly increased output. This lessening of the man-power required for industrial operation is proceeding so rapidly that civilization, if it is to be saved, must take cognizance of it. It is idle to say that the time is not ripe; that the problem is so complex that it is impossible to devise a means to meet it.

speech.para: The speeches of the honorable members for Corio and Denison were reminiscent of the objections made 30 years ago, when the wages board system was on its trial. Practically the same arguments were employed then to meet requests from industrial organizations for the introduction of shorter hours . in industry. What is the alternative? It is useless for honorable members to make speeches in this Parliament, and urge that there are so many difficulties in the way of reform that we dare not interfere with the existing system. I again remind them that, unless we take definite measures to meet the changing social conditions, the problem which now confronts us, will eventually destroy civilization. No country is free from the menace.

It is humiliating ito those of us in the Labour movement to know that while other countries are giving serious thought to the elucidation of this problem Australia is lagging behind. Innumerable instances have been cited of industries in other countries which are working the 40-hour week without any reduction of wages. In Australia, unfortunately, we can point to only a few isolated industries which have so reduced their hours of work. The majority are working 48 hours a week. Australia is a young, and an immensely wealthy, country. Therefore, it ought to be possible for us to march in the vanguard of industrial progress. We are not doing this; probably because we are not close to the manufacturing centres of the old world, and, for that reason, may not be abreast of them in economic thought. Henry Ford was one of the first of the leaders in American industry to inaugurate a 40-hour week in some of his factories and subsidiary industrial establishments. The honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Holloway) and the right honorable the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Scullin) mentioned what has been done in many other countries, but they omitted to state that Signor Mussolini recently declared publicly that a 30-hour week was the only solution for the world's industrial troubles. The honorable member for Corio probably had this in his mind when he suggested that if industry generally came down to a 30-hour week, the scientific and mechanical development which would follow- would eventually defeat the object pf the change. But that, I suggest, was a most ridiculous argument to advance. Assuming that, following the universal adoption of a 30-hour week, the application of science to industry made possible an enormously increased output, would it not be better for civilization ? Would it not indicate the possibility of a working week of 20 hours ?

talk.start.para: - What I had in mind was that the mechanical development of industry would result in larger numbers of workmen being displaced.
- But does not the honorable member see that a reduction of the hours would be better for civilization generally?
- Would the honorable member advocate the payment of the same wages for the reduced working week ?
- Of course. The trouble with the honorable member and his friends is that they are adhering to orthodox industrial principles which are fundamentally unsound.
- They are not orthodox principles; they are out of date.

- Yes, they are obsolete, and for that reason are inapplicable to the present industrial situation. If, twenty years ago, men were compelled to work 50 hours a week to provide the necessaries of life, food and clothing for themselves and their families, and meet other current expenditure, that is no reason why they should continue to work such long hours. We have gradually brought down the working hours in industry. We now recognize the principle of 48 hours, and a large proportion of our people are working only 44 hours, without interference with wage or living standards. The more recent developments in our social system have compelled us to recognize these facts, and point to the urgent need for dealing with this problem. I, therefore, hope that the Acting Leader of the House (Mr. Latham) will give sympathetic consideration to the request that has been made, and will allow Australia to take her part in the discussion of this important subject with the representatives of the nations, the majority of which approve of a reduction in working hours. Let not Australia stand by to "wait and see," as was suggested by the honorable member for Denison. Let not Australia be inarticulate; because the outcome of the conference means something for this country and civilization. It has been stated on several occasions that one-fifth of the population of the world is on the verge of starvation and 'in receipt of the dole. Unhappily the position is becoming worse every day, first, because of the existence of an obsolete monetary system, and, secondly, because of the scientific development of industry. Our field of taxation is gradually diminishing, and within a few years, huge taxation will be placed upon a relatively small number of people. What is the alternative? It is either a dictatorship or revolution. Heaven knows that the unemployed of Australia and other parts of the world have been exceedingly patient. Under, a dictatorship, they would be subdued by force, and by machine gun. If a revolution takes place, it will be a bloody revolution. The Government should instruct its delegate at Geneva to join with the majority of the representatives of other nations in respect of any recommendations that may be made.

. - There is one phase of this question which the nations of the world are compelled to face at the present moment. Whereas a decade ago, one or two nations, because of the mechanization of industry, held predominance in manufactures, to day, every nation of the world, by the use of highly mechanized methods, is producing far more than it can consume. The application and development of the machine have intensified production and displaced hundreds of thousands of operatives. The problem which is facing the business men of all nations is how to get absorbed the goods that are manufactured. They have decided that the only solution of the problem is to shorten working hours, to increase the spending power of the community, and to adopt methods of mass production and distribution. Those are the methods that will govern the national life of the people in the near future. Unless they are adopted, all nations will reach a state of chaos, and eventually revolution will result. It is argued rightly that we cannot have at the one time high purchasing power in the community, low wages, and unemployment in factories, fields and offices. No industry can hope to survive unless there is spending power in > the community. The only way to intensify consumption is to intensify employment. That decision has been reached by business men and those engaged in large industrial concerns throughout the world. According to the report of the International Labour Office of 1933, the following countries are working fewer hours a week than Australia: - Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Italy, Germany, Belgium, Poland and the Netherlands. All the big industries of those countries are working four shifts of six hours each instead of three shifts of eight hours each a day. Where there is only one shift a day the 40-hour week is being universally adopted. All governments, including Australia, called on the employers to absorb as many unemployed as possible. But some governments gave a definite lead in that direction. For instance, the German Government in September, 1932, set aside 7,000,000 reichmarks for the relief of unemployment, and offered 400 reichmarks to every employer for each additional hand employed for one year. That scheme provided a year's work for 1,750,000 additional men. The Bulgarian tobacco industry, acting upon the orders of the Government, reduced its working hours from eight hours to seven hours a day. Food industries, shipyards, electrical engineering works, cigarette industries, and others all introduced four six-hour shifts in place of three' eight-hour shifts, without any alteration of wage. The maximum hours in those industries are 40 a week. The Kellogg food manufacturers of the United States of America, reduced the working hours from eight to six a day, with a minimum wage of 4 dollars. The Vacuum Oil Company, the Standard Oil Company, paper industries, manufacturing chemists, the Indian Tyre and

speech.para: Rubber Company, Fourcault Glass Manufacturers, the largest in the world, operating both in the United States of America and Belgium, reduced their working hours from eight to six a day. The Fiat Motor Works, of Italy, with 10,000 wage workers and 1,500 staff hands, are now working 40 hours a week, with the same rate of pay as before. No men are being dismissed, and hours are being adjusted to balance the production and demand. That has been done in agreement with the unions concerned. The Minerva Motor Works, of Belgium, are now working 40 hours instead of 48 hours a week, at the same rate of pay. The Poland sugar industry is working six-hour shifts, and the Philips electrical globe works, of the Netherlands, are working 40 hours a week. Those are a few instances in which other countries have forged ahead of Australia in their efforts to change the methods of employment to meet the wonderful increase of their power to produce the necessaries of life. The spending power of the community must be increased, otherwise not only the workers, but also the whole of civilization, will suffer. The honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Holloway) has pointed out that a working week of 40 hours has been introduced into England. That country has always been slow to adopt new standards; but the economic position of the world, the intensification of machine production, the harnessing and bending of natural forces to man's will, is forcing it to realize that the machine should be a blessing to the people, and not remain as it is to-day - a curse. A social and industrial revolution has started in England. Mander Brothers, of Wolverhampton, a firm which is manufacturing paints, colours, varnishes, and inks, and whose works are the largest of their kind in England, have agreed with the general workers union to reduce hours from 47 to 40 a week, with no alteration in the rate of pay. The United .States Rubber Company, employing 25,000 workers, obtained such satisfactory results from a system of working five days and 40 hours a week that it has decided to adopt it permanently. Mr. Bata, a boot manufacturer of Czechoslovakia, employing 18,000 hands, introduced a five-day week of 40 hours, and the following year he employed 25,000 hands. This is occurring, not because the manufacturers have suddenly become philanthropic, but because the mechanization of industry is compelling the adoption of these methods. History has shown that, when unemployment in a community reaches 25 per cent., revolution will break out. To-day the employment throughout the world exceeds that percentage. The only way to prevent revolution is to make the machine the slave of the people, instead of the people being the slave of the machine. I suggest that the Government instruct its delegate at Geneva to join with the representatives of the other nations of the world in their endeavour to save humanity from destruction.

talk.start.para: . - Honorable members have listened with interest to the discussion of this problem, the difficulty of which all speakers have recognized. The Government is not adopting any dogmatic attitude with respect to it. It has made inquiries, and very interesting reports have been received from the Melbourne Trades Hall Council and the Chamber of Manufactures. Only this morning, a report was received from the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce with advice that further observations dealing specifically with the report of the Trades Hall Council would be forwarded. The Government proposes to consider all these representations, as well as the speeches made this evening, before arriving at a decision regarding the instruction to be given to Mr. J. G. McLaren,- who will represent the Commonwealth Government at Geneva.

speech.para: Whilst the decision of the Government will not be made immediately, I may be permitted to make a few general observations upon this vital subject. It is important that the 40-hour proposal should be viewed in relation to the particular problem for the solution of which it is submitted. It is made, not for the safeguarding of health or the prevention of fatigue, but in order to deal with the evil of unemployment which is sweeping over the world. Any one acquainted with industrial history is aware that whenever the reduction of hours has been proposed, there have been those who have declared that it- would mean ruin to industry. The Government is not prepared to adopt that dogmatic general attitude. This is an economic problem, but it is also a human problem, and the difficulty is that we cannot solve the human problem without first solving the economic problem. If out of kindheartedness, hours were suddenly reduced all round, and wages were increased all round, industry might crash, and the resulting unemployment cause national and social chaos and destruction. The proposal for the reduction of hours is made at this juncture to deal first with unemployment generally, and secondly, with the particular class of unemployment described as technological. There is considerable difference of opinion as to the actual volume of unemployment resulting from technological improvements and the mechanization of industry.' I have seen the proportion estimated to be as low as 10 per cent, of the original volume of unemployment, because a certain amount of re-employ' ment or new employment results from the improved mechanical and technical processes in some industries. In one of the reports recently submitted to the Government, reference is made to the results of an inquiry made in Sydney into technological unemployment; there, a skilled investigator concluded that on the balance there was practically no unemployment of this character in Australia. I shall be surprised if further inquiry confirms, that conclusion.

When the 40-hour week is considered in relation to the general problem of unemployment, certain f actors must be borne in mind. First, many industries are already working 40 hours. The report on "Hours of Work and Unemployment", prepared by the Preparatory Conference of the International Labour Office in January of this year, mentions a large number of such industries. There are other, seasonal, industries in which men must work practically throughout the hours of day' light, and in respect of them it is impossible to impose any hard and fast limitations. The second point is well put by Dr. Fritz Sitzler, in an article on " The International Reduction of Hours of Work ", published in the International Labour Review of December last. I refer to this article because it is apparently the basis of the questionnaire which is proposed to be circulated to governments as a result of the work of the preparatory conference. Dr. Sitzler emphasizes that the proposal to reduce hours is made for the purpose of dealing with the present problem of unemployment, and not for reasons of health or fatigue. He says -

quote.para: What we can and must achieve, however, is some mitigation of the existing unemployment. Any convention which is adopted must, therefore, be in the nature of a temporary emergency measure for the duration of the depression. Every State must be left free to return to its former hours of work when conditions have improved. The more clearly this reservation is imposed the greater is the possibility of success.

speech.para: That view will probably be dissented from in many quarters; but it appears to me to be indubitably correct if this proposal is really made to deal with unemployment resulting from general depression.

talk.start.para: - One would naturally expect that the results of the experiment would determine its future.

- Undoubtedly the results would be taken into account. Nearly every speaker this afternoon has recognized that this subject must be dealt with on an international basis. We live in a competitive world, and it is quite impossible for us to ignore the action taken by our competitors; but I am impressed by the contention of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Scullin) that that fact should not prevent our delegates from supporting this proposal at the international conference, if, on general grounds, it is thought to be proper. One of the fundamental difficulties is raised by the resolution of the workers' group at the preparatory conference -

quote.para: That discussion on the subject of a fortyfourhour week convention should proceed on the basis that weekly wages and monthly salaries will not be reduced by reason of the reduction of hours resulting from the adoption and application of such convention.

speech.para: That proposal was not adopted, but the conference carried a motion in these terms -

quote.para: The conference, after reviewing the various arguments advanced for and against a reduction of working hours, considers that it is one of the measures which would contribute to reducing unemployment.

The conference therefore decides to examine ite detailed aspects, taking the questions raised in Part II. of the conclusions of the report of the office as the basis of its examination, in order to reach an arrangement of an international character the methods of giving effect to which would be determined with a view to rendering possible the maintenance of the standard of life of the wage-earners.

speech.para: The workers' group subscribed to that resolution on the understanding that there was no vital difference of intention or principle between it and their resolution. That is an example of what often happens at international conferences at which a formula is devised which, in words, meets the case, but covers a field upon which there is acute and wide divergence of opinion. Whether the reduction of hours, is to be accompanied by a reduction of wages is a fundamental consideration. That is a very difficult point, because there is the risk of the adoption of such a plan working out in this way: Overhead costs remain constant, or are increased; labour costs go up per unit of labour achievement; and prices rise. It is hard enough for the world to purchase goods at existing prices. If those prices rise, how is there to be any alleviation of the position when, generally speaking, the same wage fund is distributed over a smaller number of hours ?

There is one particularly interesting point in Dr. Sitzler's article that I should like to bring to the attention of honorable members. The author refers to the difficulty of providing that wages shall not be reduced, and points out that no agreement can fix wages all over the world. Accordingly, he says, it is impossible to prescribe a fixed supplement to wages which are free to fluctuate; and it is by no means easy to provide that, when hours are reduced from 48 to 40, hourly rates shall rise by one-sixth. He goes on to say -

quote.para: If wages were to be raised everywhere in proportion to the reduction in hours, this would be to the disadvantage of countries with high wages.

speech.para: I point out that Australia is a high-wage country. He continues -

quote.para: Suppose that competing industries in two countries reduce their weekly hours of work from 48 to 40, and adjust wages by raising them 20 per cent. Then the wage supplement would be 12 pfennigs for an hourly wage of 00 pfennigs, and 20 pfennigs for an hourly wage of 1 mark. The previous wage difference of 40 pfennigs per hour would thus be increased to 48, so that the industry paying the lower wages would still further increase its advantage over the other. This would probably lead to more intensive rationalization in the industry paying the higher wages, and, therefore, in turn to a corresponding dismissal of workers.

speech.para: That is a very interesting view of the matter, which shows how complicated it is. I, however, do not desire, particularly at this hour, to occupy the time of the House further.

I conclude by saying that the Government is glad that there has been at least this opportunity for some discussion of this very important 'subject. I assure honorable members that consideration will be given to it, with an earnest desire to make any contribution that we may be able to make towards solving the Very grave problem of unemployment. The decision of the Government certainly will not be dictated by any doctrinaire idea drawn from the past.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The House adjourned at 6.35 p.m. to a date and hour to be fixed by Mr. Speaker.

para.inline: The following answers to questions were circulated: -

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice -

quote.para: In view of the admirable report on the cause of chronic nephritis in Queensland, by the Chief Quarantine Officer, Dr. Cilento, M.D., B.S., &c. (Health Journal, December, 1032), which indicates that a possible cause is from the painting of wooden houses, will the Minister state whether, in the event of such painting being a cause of chronic nephritis in Queensland to a greater extent than in other States, this evil would be removed if oxide of zinc instead of lead were used in paint?

talk.start.para: - The investigations of Dr. Cilento do not clearly incriminate the use of lead painting of wooden houses as a cause of chronic nephritis in Queensland. In any case, legislative action which might be thought necessary as a result of this or other investigations is a matter for the State Government.
asked the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Has his attention been directed to the Labor Daily of 24th March, wherein it is stated that there is danger of food poisoning from tins of fruit unfit for consumption?
Will he request his department to consider whether it would not be a great safeguard of the health of the people if all tin receptacles containing food were marked with the date of canning?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follow: -

item.para: The danger of food poisoning from tins of fruit unfit for consumption is clearly recognized and covered by existing health legislation and established practice in the several States.

Any consideration of the adoption of marking of all tin receptacles containing food with the date of canning is a matter which falls within the jurisdiction of the individual State under relevant pure food and health legislation.

talk.start.para: asked the Postmaster-General, upon notice -

item.para: In view of the large amount of money paid by the Commonwealth Government for rents for government offices inconveniently scattered over Melbourne, will the Minister bring under the notice of the Cabinet the necessity of completing the Melbourne Post Office, and thus providing offices for all the Commonwealth departments?

Will he inquire from the Melbourne City Council, in view of the urgent need of helping the unemployed in Melbourne in the building trade, if that council would assist the Government in removing the present unsightly structure and completing a beautiful building, thus helping the unemployed and beautifying the City of Melbourne in honour of its centenary?

talk.start.para: - Consideration will be given to the honorable member's proposals, but it is pointed out that the magnitude of the undertaking would be such that it is most unlikely the Government would find it possible to justify the raising of the very large sum of money which would be needed for the purpose.
asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

quote.para: If Australia's total contributions to the League of Nations, on the basis of 27 units out of a total of 1,012 units, amounts to 408,040, what was the total cost to the world of the League of Nations to the 30th June, 1932?

talk.start.para: (through Mr Latham) - The total expenditure of the League of Nations to 31st December, 1931, up to which date the information is available here, was 251,344,894 gold francs (approximately 10,000,000 gold).
asked the Treasurer, upon notice -

item.para: What is the proportion recouped by the States (giving amount for each State separately) of pensions granted under section 84 of the Commonwealth Constitution?

Excluding old-age, invalid, and war pensions, payments under Commonwealth Superannuation Act, and payments under section 84 of the Commonwealth Constitution, what is the amount paid by the Commonwealth Government in pensions, and how is this amount made up?

talk.start.para: (through Mr. Latham). - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follow: -

item.para: Proportions recouped by the States of pensions granted under section 84 of the Constitution are -
The amount is 6,034, and is made up as follows: -

subdebateinfo.title: The Census: Preference to Returned Soldiers

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: Are ex-Imperial and ex-South African soldiers eligible to sit for the proposed census examinations?
If not, will arrangements be made to allow them to sit, and will the time for receipt of applications be extended for this purpose?

talk.start.para: (throughMr. Latham). - Any person coming within the definition of returned soldier as given in section 7 of the Public Service Act is eligible to sit for the examination. This definition does not cover ex-South African soldiers, but includes those ex-soldiers who were horn in Australia or resident in Australia within six months prior to enlistment, and who at any time during the war served with satisfactory record in a naval or military expeditionary force raised in the United Kingdom or in any British dominion.

(throughMr. Latham). - Information is being obtained, and will be made available as soon as possible in reply to a series of questions asked,upon notice, by the honorable member for Oxley (Mr. Baker)in regard to entrance examinations for admission to the Public Service.

subdebateinfo.title: Deputy Director op Posts and Telegraphs, Melbourne

talk.start.para: asked the Postmaster-General, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that the Deputy Director of Posts and Telegraphs, Melbourne, in accordance with customary procedure now followed, should have relinquished official duties at the end of March, prior to retirement?
Has he so retired or been granted furlough?
If he did neither retire nor proceed on furlough, why has he been permitted to continue in office when other officern have been required to relinquish duty on the due date?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follow: -

item.para: Mr. Christie will attain the age of 65 years on 11th May, 1934. He is eligible for twelve months furlough and will therefore not be due to commence such furlough until 11th May, 1933.

subdebateinfo.title: Postmaster-General's Department: Charges - Operating Costs - Reserve for Depreciation.

talk.start.para: - On the 29th March, the honorable member for

question.para: Richmond (Mr. R. Green) asked the following questions, upon notice: -

item.para: What are the percentage increases or decreases in rates charged to the public by the post office, comparing the year 1931 with 1914 and 1923, in respect of (a) postal charges, (b) telegraph charges, and (c) telephone charges?
When was the last increase made in postal rates?
What was the additional revenue, if any, received during the year 1930-31 as the result of that increase?
When was the last increase made in telegraph rates?
What additional revenue (if any) was received as a result of that increase during the year 1930-31?
When was the last increase made in telephone charges?
What was the additional revenue (if any) received as the result of that increase during the year 1930-31 ?
What was the cost of operating, traffic management, and incidentals in the telephone branch to every 1 of total revenue in that branch during the years 1922-23 and 1930-31?

Of this amount, what increase, if any, was received (a) from long distance telephone calls, (b) from increased charges for local calls in country offices, and (c) from increased charges for press calls or long distance calls?

question.para: I am now in a position to furnish the following information: -

item.para: The changes made are of such a character that it would be difficult to express them as percentage; moreover the work entailed would be considerable. The honorable member is reminded that the Post Office Guide, for the years in question, contains a complete statement of the actual charges then current.
Parcels, 16th December, 1929; other mail matter, 4th August, 1930.
It is impracticable to assess the additional revenue arising from the revised charges, because of the effects resulting from the depression and other disturbing factors.
1st October, 1920.
The amount cannot be assessed. The varying factors affecting business over a period of more than ten years are too involved to enable a calculation to be made.
10th December, 1929.
The figure cannot be assessed owing to the reasons mentioned in reply to 3.
See reply to No. 7.

question.para: On the 29th March, the honorable member for Richmond (Mr. R. Green) asked the following questions, upon notice: -

item.para: What was the cost of salaries, wages and contingencies to every 1 of total revenue in the Postal branch for the years 1922-23 and 1930-31?
What was the cost of operating, traffic management, and incidentals to every 1 of total revenue in the Telegraph branch for the years 1922-23 and 1930-31?
What are the rentals and cost per call for local and a 150 miles long-distance call in America, Argentine, Canada, South Africa, Great Britain, and New Zealand?
Has there been any increase or reduction between Melbourne and Sydney during the past two years; if so, by what amount?

question.para: I am now in a position to furnish the following information: -

item.para: According to the latest information available the annual charges for telephone services in the more important cities of the various countries mentioned are as follow: -
Australia (Sydney and Melbourne) 5 10s.;1d. for each local call.
United States of America (Cleveland) 13 15s.; 1,020 local calls free (additional calls 2d. to ld. each).
Canada (Montreal), 17 10s.; local calls free.
South Africa (Cape Town), 9. Nine hundred local calls free (additional calls 1d. each).
Great Britain (London), 8;1d. for each local call.
New Zealand (Wellington), 15; local calls free.
Argentina, no information available.

The day rates for a trunk line call not exceeding three minutes, over a distance of 150 miles, in the countries under notice, are Australia, 2s.; New Zealand, 2s. 6d.; South Africa. 3s.; United States of America, 3s. 4d.; Great Britain, 3s. 6d.; Canada, 3s.11d.; Argentina, no information available.
No.

question.para: On the 29th March, the honorable member for Richmond (Mr. R. Green) asked the following questions, upon notice: -

item.para: Has the Auditor-General expressed any opinion as to the adequacy or otherwise of the basis upon which the reserve for depreciation in the Postmaster-General's Department is established?
If so, will the Postmaster-General supply the House with any such expressions of opinion over the past ten years?
If no such opinion has been expressed, will the Postmaster-General obtain from the Auditor-General his views on the existing basis of depreciation?
Is it a fact that as at 30th June, 1919, the reserve was 2.26 per cent. of the total value of fixed assets and plant of the Postmaster-General's Department?
Was the reserve 4.4 per cent. as at 30th June, 1931?

If so, how does the Postmaster-General justify an increase of only 2.14 per cent. over a period of twelve years, in view of the fact that commercial experience has shown that in all business enterprises much more liberal rates are necessary to safeguard the solvency of the undertaking?

Will the Postmaster-General give consideration to the provision of depreciation based on the estimated useful life of the assets in order to equalize the annual charge for such depreciation and to guard against the possibility of serious over-capitalization?
Will the Postmaster-General state why at least the rates of depreciation allowed for Federal Income Tax purposes (7 to 10 per cent.) are not applied to the assets of the Postal Department ?
What additional amount would be required annually if the rates allowed for Federal Income Tax purposes were applied to the assets of the Postal Department?

Will the Postmaster-General explain why, in the report of his department for the year 1929-30, table 8, the total net value of assets on the 30th June, 1930, is shown as 51,669,440, whilst in table 8 of the following year's report, the total net value on the 1st July, 1930, is shown as 51,748,860?
How does the difference of 79,420 arise?

question.para: I am now in a position to furnish the following information: -

item.para: The departmental profit and loss accounts for 1912-13 and 1916-17 were subject to special audit examination, and a report submitted that the accounting methods and principles adopted by the department were satisfactory. No fundamental changes have been made in the system since that time.

item.label: 2 and 3.
item.para: See reply to 1.
Yes.
Yes.

The question of a depreciation reserve is determined very largely by the nature of the assets and the manner in which they are maintained. Departmental working expenses include the total cost of day to day maintenance, repairs, renewals, and, to a considerable extent, loss on plant retired from service.
The whole question of depreciation has been reviewed exhaustively during the past two or three years, and a further study is nearing completion.
The department's commercial accounts have no direct relationship with depreciation allowances made for federal income tax purposes.
The items are not generally applicable, and even if they were a very large amount of labour would be entailed in making the calculation suggested.

The statement of the 30th June, 1930. covers assets of the telegraph, telephone, and postal branches, but in the statement for the following year the assets which had been purchased for broadcasting purposes were added.
See reply to 10.

talk.start.para: (through Mr Latham). -

question.para: On the 28th March, the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Holloway) asked the following question, upon notice: -

quote.para: What is the amount of capital invested, the rate of interest on same, the percentage return on capital invested, percentage of working expenses to revenue, percentage of interest to revenue on the Commonwealth Government railways for 1932, compared with those items for the railways of each of the States of Australia, New Zealand, Canadian National, Canadian Pacific, United Kingdom, South Africa]] and German railways, for the year 1932, or the latest year for which figures are available?

question.para: The following statement has been prepared from information available in the office of the Commissioner of Commonwealth Railways: -

talk.start.para: . - On the 4th April, the honorable member for Brisbane (Mr. George Lawson) referred to the matter of the issue of military clothing to the unemployed in Brisbane, and asked what quantity would be available for distribution before the winter months.

question.para: I am now in a position to inform the honorable member that part-worn and unserviceable military clothing which is of no further use for military purposes becomes available from time to time, but the quantities are small. The following part-worn articles will shortly be available for issue to the Government of Queensland for distribution in that State to those in necessitous circumstances: -

talk.start.para: . - On the 4th April, the honorable member for the Northern Territory (Mr. Nelson) referred to a report concerning a seaplane said to have been seen off Darwin. I promised to give consideration to the honorable member's question, and am now in a position to inform him that the report by a Chinese that a seaplane flew over the harbour at Darwin on Friday, the 31st March, is not confirmed from other sources. So far as the Defence Department is concerned, it is considered that circumstances do not warrant expenditure being incurred in the despatch to Darwin of patrol boats or seaplanes. The question of the provision of a suitable garrison at Darwin is at present under consideration.
